Award.AwardTitle: Building capacity in Bayesian analysis for practicing ecologists
Award.AbstractNarration:
Traditionally, ecologists used designed experiments and associated statistical procedures to learn about the environment. Although this approach provided valuable insight, it has become clear that many pressing problems in ecology cannot be solved using classical methods for design and analysis. In particular, ecological researchers need new methods to honestly represent uncertainty, to use data from multiple sources, to estimate quantities that cannot be observed, and to make forecasts about the environment. Hierarchical Bayesian methods meet these needs, allowing investigators to address questions that heretofore were seen as too complex to answer. Many ecologists at universities and management agencies recognize the promise of these methods but lack an efficient way to learn them. The research team will offer intensive training on hierarchical Bayesian methods to post-doctoral researchers, academic faculty, and scientists at agencies and non-governmental organizations.

Participation by groups under-represented in science will be enhanced by holding one of the workshops at the University of Puerto Rico in Rio Piedras. A listserv on the application of Bayesian methods in ecology will be developed. A website with open access to training materials will be maintained. The impact of the project will be amplified several fold as newly trained scientists apply Bayesian methods in their research, teaching, and decision-support.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research team was funded by the Population and Community Ecology Program during 2013-2016 to offer four, annual workshops providing intensive training in Bayesian modeling to 20-25 ecologists. Three hundred sixty six people applied to attend the workshops over the four years, 101 for the 2016 workshop. Participants were selected based on their ability to use the training to teach and mentor, to enhance research of high impact, and to influence policy and management. Eighty five university faculty, agency scientists, and post-docs were trained. Participants included 50 males and 35 females representing a broad range of career stages, from recent PhDs to full professors, from eight countries (Australia, Brazil, Canada, Mexico, Nigeria, Panama, Spain and United Kingdom), two U.S. territories (Puerto Rico and Virgin Islands), the District of Columbia, and 32 U.S. states. Seventy-seven percent of participants came from U.S. institutions. Research interests spanned all sub-disciplines of ecology.

Intellectual Merit

Seven journal articles (Carrillo-Rubio et al., 2014; Hobbs et al., 2015; Raiho et al., 2015; Hooten and Hobbs, 2015; Campbell et al., 2016; Ketz et al., 2016; Wilson et al., 2016)[1] and a book (Hobbs and Hooten, 2015) formally acknowledge support from this award.

Broader Impacts

Laboratory exercises useful in teaching Bayesian methods have been made publicly available on an online GitHub repository (https://github.com/nthobbs50/BayesLabs). Eleven graduate students and post-doctoral fellows participated in laboratory sessions, gaining teaching experience helping participants with laboratory exercises.

Rose Shaw Consulting conducted an independent assessment of the training during June, 2015. Dr. Shaw has served as an external evaluator for 75 projects supported by the National Science Foundation, the National Institute of Health, and other federal agencies. Seventy-one of 85 participants (84%) responded to the survey she designed and distributed. The high-points of her assessment include the following. Respondents were asked retrospectively to rate their level of expertise for reviewing papers and proposals that use Bayesian analysis before and as a result of participating in the workshop. The rating scale was 1 (no expertise) to 10 (highest expertise). The average score before the course was 2.2 and the average post-course was 6.4. The Cohen effect score (Cohen, 1988) was 2.9, considered “Large” for an educational intervention. Products identified by participants that were influenced by their participation in the workshop included papers for peer-reviewed journals (40)[2], books and monographs (6), proposals (30), successful grants (18), new courses (16), modified courses (27), graduate theses (17), and technical reports supporting policy and management (17). Forty five percent of the participants responded that they would have been unable to attend the course without the $1000 provided by the project to partially offset their travel costs; 30% said they might have been able to attend, and 25% indicated that support was not necessary.

Literature cited

Campbell, E. E., W. J. Parton, J. L. Soong, K. Paustian, N. T. Hobbs, and M. F. Cotrufo, 2016. Using litter chemistry controls on microbial processes to partition litter carbon fluxes with the litter decomposition and leaching (lidel) model. Soil Biology and Biochemistry 100:160–174.

Carrillo-Rubio, E., M. Kery, S. J. Morreale, P. J. Sullivan, B. Gardner, E. G. Cooch, and J. P. Lassoie, 2014. Use of multispecies occupancy models to evaluate the response of bird communities to forest degradation associated with logging. Conservation Biology 28:1034–1044.

Cohen, J., 1988. Statistical Power Analysis for the Behavioral Sciences. Lawrence Erlbaum, Hillsdale, N.J., USA.

Hobbs, N. T., C. Geremia, J. Treanor, R. Walllen, P. J. White, M. B. Hooten, and J. C. Rhyan, 2015. State-space modeling to support management of brucellosis in the Yellowstone bison population. Ecological Monographs 85:2–28.

Hobbs, N. T. and M. B. Hooten, 2015. Bayesian models: A statistical primer for ecologists. Princeton University Press, Princeton New Jersey, USA.

Hooten, M. B. and N. T. Hobbs, 2015. A guide to Bayesian model selection for ecologists. Ecological Mongraphs 85:3–28.

Ketz, A. C., T. L. Johnson, R. J. Monello, and N. T. Hobbs, 2016. Informing management with monitoring data: The value of Bayesian forecasting. Ecosphere 7:e01587–n/a.

Raiho, A., M. B. Hooten, S. Bates, and N. T. Hobbs, 2015. Forecasting the effects of fertility control on overabundant ungulates. PLOS ONE 10:e0143122. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0143122.

Wilson, R. R., E. V. Regehr, K. D. Rode, and M. St Martin, 2016. Invariant polar bear habitat selection during a period of sea ice loss. Proceedings of the Royal Society B-Biological Sciences 283.

 

[1] Hooten and Hobbs 2015 acknowledged support from NSF award 1145200 but entered an incorrect award number (000347455) in the acknowledgement.

[2] Included 17 published papers, 12 in preparation, 7 submitted, 4 in review, and one in press when the survey was conducted.
